pages.title: Chamfered square tiling
pages.text:
{| class=wikitable style="float:right;" width="340" ! style="background-color:#e7dcc3;" colspan=2|Chamfered square tiling |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan=2 |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-equal.svg|160px]][[image:Chamfered_square_tiling-equal-3color.svg|160px]]
[[File:Chamfered square tiling-3color2.svg|160px]][[File:Chamfered square tiling-4color.svg|160px]]
4 colorings |- | style="background-color:#e7dcc3;" |[[List_of_planar_symmetry_groups#Wallpaper_groups|Symmetry]]||p4m, [4,4], *442 |- | style="background-color:#e7dcc3;" |Rotation symmetry||p4, [4,4]+, 442 |- | style="background-color:#e7dcc3;" |[[Dual polyhedron|Dual]]||[[Semikis square tiling]] |- | style="background-color:#e7dcc3;" |Properties|| |} In [[geometry]], the '''chamfered square tiling''' or '''semitruncated square tiling''' is a tiling of the [[Euclidean plane]]. It is a [[square tiling]] with each edge [[Chamfer (geometry)|chamfered]] into new hexagonal faces. It can also be seen as the intersection of two [[truncated square tiling]]s with offset positions. And its appearance is similar to a truncated square tiling, except only half of the vertices have been truncated, leading to its descriptive name ''[[Conway_polyhedron_notation#Semi-operators|semitruncated]] square tiling''. == Usage and Names in tiling patterns== In floor tiling, this pattern with small squares has been labeled as ''Metro Broadway Matte'' and ''alternate corner square tile''.[http://www.houseplanshelper.com/tile-patterns-gallery.html Tile Patterns Gallery] With large squares it has been called a ''Dijon tile pattern''. As 3 rows of rectangles, it has been called a ''basketweave tiling'' and ''triple block tile pattern ''.[http://www.toppstiles.co.uk/style-and-inspiration/laying-patterns Laying Patterns] == Variations== Variations can be seen in different degrees of ''truncation''. As well, geometric variations exist within a given symmetry. The second row shows the tilings with a 45 degree rotation which also look a little different. Lower symmetry forms are related to the [[cairo pentagonal tiling]] with axial edges expanded into [[rectangle]]s. {| class=wikitable width=720 !colspan=3| *432 symmetry forms||colspan=3| 2*22 symmetry forms |- !||Shallow
(Dijon tile)||Deep
(alternate corner square tile) ||Flat
(Triple block)
(Basketweave)||Rectangular||Concave |- |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-equal.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-shallow.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-deep.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-flat.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-unequal.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-concave.svg|120px]] |- |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-equal-45.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-shallow-45.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-deep-45.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-flat-45.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-unequal-45.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-concave-45.svg|120px]] |} The chiral forms can look similar to the [[pythagorean tiling]]. {| class=wikitable |+ 442 symmetry forms !Flat||Shallow||Deep||Concave |- |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-equal-rotational.svg|160px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-shallow-rotational.svg|160px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-deep-rotational.svg|160px]] |[[File:Chamfered_square_tiling-concave-rotational.svg|160px]] |} == Semikis square tiling== The dual tiling looks like a square tiling with half of the squares divided into central triangles. It can be called a [[semikis]] square tiling, as alternate squares with [[kis operator]] applied. It can be seen as 4 sets of parallel lines. :[[File:Dual_chamfered_square_tiling.svg|240px]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Tessellation}} {{commons category}} [[Category:Euclidean tilings]]

pages.title: Elongated triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform tiles db|Uniform tiling stat table|Uet}} In [[geometry]], the '''elongated triangular tiling''' is a [[Tiling by regular polygons|semiregular tiling]] of the Euclidean plane. There are three triangles and two squares on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]]. It is named as a [[triangular tiling]] [[elongation (geometry)|elongated]] by rows of squares, and given [[Schläfli symbol]] {3,6}:e. [[John Horton Conway|Conway]] calls it a '''isosnub quadrille'''.Conway, 2008, p.288 table There are 3 [[List of regular polytopes#Euclidean tilings|regular]] and 8 [[List of uniform tilings|semiregular tilings]] in the plane. This tiling is similar to the [[snub square tiling]] which also has 3 triangles and two squares on a vertex, but in a different order. == Construction== It is also the only convex [[uniform tiling]] that can't be created as a [[Wythoff construction]]. It can be constructed as alternate layers of [[apeirogonal prism]]s and [[apeirogonal antiprism]]s. == Uniform colorings == There is one [[uniform coloring]]s of an elongated triangular tiling. Two 2-uniform colorings have a single vertex figure, 11123, with two colors of squares, but are not 1-uniform, repeated either by reflection or glide reflection, or in general each row of squares can be shifted around independently. The 2-uniform tilings are also called [[Archimedean coloring]]s. There are infinite variations of these Archimedean colorings by arbitrary shifts in the square row colorings. {| class=wikitable |- !11122 (1-uniform) !colspan=2|11123 (2-uniform or 1-Archimedean) |- |[[File:Elongated triangular tiling 1.png|150px]] |[[File:Elongated triangular tiling 3.png|150px]] |[[File:Elongated triangular tiling 2.png|150px]] |- align=center |cmm (2*22) |pmg (22*) |pgg (22×) |} == Circle packing == The elongated triangular tiling can be used as a [[circle packing]], placing equal diameter circles at the center of every point. Every circle is in contact with 5 other circles in the packing ([[kissing number]]).Order in Space: A design source book, Keith Critchlow, p.74-75, circle pattern F :[[File:1-uniform-8-circlepack.svg|200px]] == Related tilings == Sections of stacked triangles and squares can be combined into radial forms. This mixes two vertex configurations, 3.3.3.4.4 and 3.3.4.3.4 on the transitions. Twelve copies are needed to fill the plane with different center arrangements. The duals will mix in [[cairo pentagonal tiling]] pentagons.[https://twitter.com/SumDumThum/status/1074929556203614209 aperiodic tilings by towers] Andrew Osborne 2018 {| class=wikitable |+ Example radial forms !Center||colspan=2|Triangle||colspan=2|Square||colspan=2|Hexagon |- align=center ![[Dihedral group|Symmetry]]||[3]||[3]+||[2]||[4]+||[6]||[6]+ |- align=center |align=center|[[File:Tower elonaged triangular tiling.svg|80px]]
Tower |[[File:Triangular_radial_elonaged_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Triangle2_elongated_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Square radial elongated triangular tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Square2 radial elongated triangular tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Point_radial_elongated_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Spiral_elongated_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |- |align=center|[[File:Dual tower elongated triangular tiling.svg|80px]]
Dual |[[File:Dual triangular_radial_elonaged_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Dual triangle2_elongated_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Dual square radial elongated triangular tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Dual square2 radial elongated triangular tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Dual point_radial_elongated_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |[[File:Dual_spiral_elongated_triangular_tiling.svg|160px]] |} === Symmetry mutations=== It is first in a series of symmetry mutations[http://www.google.com/search?q=Two-Dimensional+Symmetry+Mutation ''Two Dimensional symmetry Mutations'' by Daniel Huson] with [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane#Quadrilateral domains|hyperbolic uniform tiling]]s with 2*''n''2 [[orbifold notation]] symmetry, [[vertex figure]] 4.''n''.4.3.3.3, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node|ultra|node_h|n|node_h|ultra|node_1}}. Their duals have hexagonal faces in the hyperbolic plane, with [[face configuration]] V4.''n''.4.3.3.3. {| class=wikitable |+ Symmetry mutation 2*n2 of uniform tilings: 4.''n''.4.3.3.3 |- !4.2.4.3.3.3 !4.3.4.3.3.3 !4.4.4.3.3.3 |- !2*22 !2*32 !2*42 |- |[[File:Elongated triangular tiling 4.2.4.3.3.3.png|150px]] |[[File:Uniform tiling 4.3.4.3.3.3.png|150px]] |[[File:Hyper 4.4.4.3.3.3a.png|150px]] |- align=center |{{CDD|node|infin|node_h|2x|node_h|infin|node_1}} |{{CDD|node|ultra|node_h|3|node_h|ultra|node_1}} or {{CDD|branch_hh|2a2b-cross|nodes_01}} |{{CDD|node|ultra|node_h|4|node_h|ultra|node_1}} or {{CDD|label4|branch_hh|2a2b-cross|nodes_01}} |} There are four related [[2-uniform tiling]]s, mixing 2 or 3 rows of triangles or squares.{{cite journal | first=D. |last=Chavey | title=Tilings by Regular Polygons—II: A Catalog of Tilings | url=https://www.beloit.edu/computerscience/faculty/chavey/catalog/ | journal=Computers & Mathematics with Applications | year=1989 | volume=17 | pages=147–165 | doi=10.1016/0898-1221(89)90156-9|ref=harv}}http://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/symmetry/uniftil.htm {| class=wikitable !Double elongated !Triple elongated !Half elongated !One third elongated |- |[[File:2-uniform n4.svg|160px]] |[[File:2-uniform n3.svg|160px]] |[[File:2-uniform n14.svg|160px]] |[[File:2-uniform n15.svg|160px]] |} === Prismatic pentagonal tiling=== {{Infobox face-uniform tiling |name=Prismatic pentagonal tiling |image=Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform One 7) 3.3.3.4.4.png |type=[[List of uniform planar tilings|Dual uniform tiling]] |coxeter={{CDD|node|infin|node_fh|2x|node_fh|infin|node_f1}}
{{CDD|node_fh|infin|node_fh|2x|node_fh|infin|node_f1}} |symmetry=cmm, [∞,2+,∞], (2*22) |faces=[[pentagon|irregular pentagons]] V3.3.3.4.4 [[File: V3.3.3.4.4.png|53px|right]] |dual=Elongated triangular tiling |properties=[[face-transitive]]|}} The prismatic pentagonal tiling is a [[List of uniform planar tilings|dual uniform tiling]] in the Euclidean plane. It is one of 15 known [[isohedral figure|isohedral]] [[pentagon tiling]]s. It can be seen as a stretched [[hexagonal tiling]] with a set of parallel bisecting lines through the hexagons. [[John Horton Conway|Conway]] calls it a iso(4-)pentille. Each of its pentagonal [[face (geometry)|faces]] has three 120° and two 90° angles. It is related to the [[Cairo pentagonal tiling]] with [[face configuration]] V3.3.4.3.4. ==== Geometric variations==== Monohedral [[Pentagonal tiling#Monohedral convex pentagonal tilings|pentagonal tiling]] type 6 has the same topology, but two edge lengths and a lower p2 (2222) [[wallpaper group]] symmetry: {| class=wikitable |- align=center |'''[[File:P5-type6.png|200px]]''' |'''[[File:Prototile p5-type6.png|200px]]
a=d=e, b=c
B+D=180°, 2B=E''' |} ====Related 2-uniform dual tilings==== There are four related 2-uniform dual tilings, mixing in rows of squares or hexagons (the prismatic pentagon is schematically half-square half-hexagon). {| class=wikitable !Dual: Double Elongated !Dual: Triple Elongated !Dual: Half Elongated !Dual: 1/3 Elongated |- align=center |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Two 17) 4.4.4.4, 3.3.3.4.4 I.png|alt=|160x160px]] |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Two 18) 4.4.4.4, 3.3.3.4.4 II.png|alt=|160x160px]] |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Two 19) 3.3.3.3.3.3, 3.3.3.4.4 I.png|alt=|160x160px]] |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Two 20) 3.3.3.3.3.3, 3.3.3.4.4 II.png|alt=|160x160px]] |- align=center |Dual: [[Euclidean tilings by convex regular polygons#/media/File:2-uniform n4.svg|V[44; 33.42]1 (t=2,e=4)]] |Dual: [[Euclidean tilings by convex regular polygons#/media/File:2-uniform n3.svg|V[44; 33.42]2 (t=3,e=5)]] |Dual: [[Euclidean tilings by convex regular polygons#/media/File:2-uniform n14.svg|V[36; 33.42]1 (t=3,e=4)]] |Dual: [[Euclidean tilings by convex regular polygons#/media/File:2-uniform n15.svg|V[36; 33.42]2 (t=4,e=5)]] |} ==See also== * [[Tilings of regular polygons]] * [[Elongated triangular prismatic honeycomb]] * [[Gyroelongated triangular prismatic honeycomb]] == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == {{Commons category|Uniform tiling 3-3-3-4-4}} {{Commons category|Prismatic pentagonal tiling}} * {{cite book|author1=[[Branko Grünbaum|Grünbaum, Branko]] |author2=Shephard, G. C. | title=Tilings and Patterns| location=New York | publisher=W. H. Freeman | year=1987 | isbn=0-7167-1193-1}} (Chapter 2.1: ''Regular and uniform tilings'', p. 58-65) *{{The Geometrical Foundation of Natural Structure (book)}} p37 * John H. Conway, Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143320/https://akpeters.com/product.asp?ProdCode=2205] * Keith Critchlow, ''Order in Space: A design source book'', 1970, p. 69-61, Pattern Q2, Dual p. 77-76, pattern 6 * Dale Seymour and Jill Britton, ''Introduction to Tessellations'', 1989, {{ISBN|978-0866514613}}, pp. 50–56 ==External links== * {{MathWorld | urlname=UniformTessellation | title=Uniform tessellation}} * {{MathWorld | urlname=SemiregularTessellation | title=Semiregular tessellation}} * {{KlitzingPolytopes|flat.htm#2D|2D Euclidean tilings|elong( x3o6o ) - etrat - O4}} {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Euclidean tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Semiregular tilings]] [[Category:Triangular tilings]]

pages.title: Hexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{More footnotes|date=March 2011}} {{Uniform tiles db|Reg tiling stat table|Uh}} In [[geometry]], the '''hexagonal tiling''' or '''hexagonal tessellation''' is a [[regular tiling]] of the [[Euclidean plane]], in which three [[hexagon]]s meet at each vertex. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {6,3} or ''t''{3,6} (as a truncated triangular tiling). English mathematician [[John Horton Conway|John Conway]] calls it a '''hextille'''. The internal angle of the hexagon is 120 degrees so three hexagons at a point make a full 360 degrees. It is one of [[List of regular polytopes#Euclidean tilings|three regular tilings of the plane]]. The other two are the [[triangular tiling]] and the [[square tiling]]. == Applications == The hexagonal tiling is the densest way to [[sphere packing|arrange circles]] in two dimensions. The [[Honeycomb conjecture]] states that the hexagonal tiling is the best way to divide a surface into regions of equal area with the least total perimeter. The optimal three-dimensional structure for making honeycomb (or rather, soap bubbles) was investigated by [[Lord Kelvin]], who believed that the [[Kelvin structure]] (or [[body-centered cubic]] lattice) is optimal. However, the less regular [[Weaire–Phelan structure]] is slightly better. This structure exists naturally in the form of [[graphite]], where each sheet of [[graphene]] resembles chicken wire, with strong covalent carbon bonds. Tubular graphene sheets have been synthesised; these are known as [[carbon nanotube]]s. They have many potential applications, due to their high [[tensile strength]] and electrical properties. [[Silicene]] is similar. [[Chicken wire]] consists of a hexagonal lattice (often not regular) of wires. File:Kissing-2d.svg |The densest [[circle packing]] is arranged like the hexagons in this tiling File:Chicken Wire close-up.jpg |[[Chicken wire]] fencing File:Graphene xyz.jpg |[[Graphene]] File:Carbon nanotube zigzag povray.PNG |A [[carbon nanotube]] can be seen as a hexagon tiling on a [[Cylinder (geometry)|cylindrical]] surface The hexagonal tiling appears in many crystals. In three dimensions, the [[face-centered cubic]] and [[hexagonal close packing]] are common crystal structures. They are the densest known sphere packings in three dimensions, and are believed to be optimal. Structurally, they comprise parallel layers of hexagonal tilings, similar to the structure of graphite. They differ in the way that the layers are staggered from each other, with the face-centered cubic being the more regular of the two. Pure [[copper]], amongst other materials, forms a face-centered cubic lattice. {{Clear}} == Uniform colorings == There are three distinct [[uniform coloring]]s of a hexagonal tiling, all generated from reflective symmetry of [[Wythoff construction]]s. The (''h'',''k'') represent the periodic repeat of one colored tile, counting hexagonal distances as ''h'' first, and ''k'' second. The same counting is used in the [[Goldberg polyhedra]], with a notation {''p''+,3}''h'',''k'', and can be applied to hyperbolic tilings for ''p''>6. {| class="wikitable" width=640 !k-uniform !colspan=3|1-uniform !colspan=2|2-uniform !colspan=2|3-uniform |- align=center ![[List of planar symmetry groups|Symmetry]] |colspan=2|p6m, (*632) | p3m1, (*333) |colspan=2|p6m, (*632) |colspan=2|p6, (632) |- !Picture |[[File:Uniform tiling 63-t0.svg|100px]] |[[File:Uniform tiling 63-t12.svg|100px]] |[[File:Uniform tiling 333-t012.svg|100px]] |[[File:Truncated rhombille tiling.png|100px]] |[[File:Hexagonal tiling 4-colors.svg|100px]] |[[File:Hexagonal tiling 2-1.svg|100px]] |[[File:Hexagonal tiling 7-colors.svg|100px]] |- align=center !Colors !1 !2 !3 !2 !4 !2 !7 |- align=center !(h,k) |(1,0) |colspan=2|(1,1) |colspan=2|(2,0) |colspan=2|(2,1) |- align=center ![[Schläfli symbol|Schläfli]] |{6,3} |t{3,6} |t{3[3]} |colspan=2| |colspan=2| |- align=center ![[Wythoff symbol|Wythoff]] | 3 | 6 2 | 2 6 | 3 | 3 3 3 | |colspan=2| |colspan=2| |- align=center ![[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram|Coxeter]] |{{CDD|node_1|6|node|3|node}} |{{CDD|node_1|3|node_1|6|node}} |{{CDD|node_1|split1|branch_11}} |colspan=2| |colspan=2| |- align=center ![[Conway polyhedron notation|Conway]] |H |tΔ | |cH | |colspan=2| |} The 3-color tiling is a tessellation generated by the order-3 [[permutohedron]]s. === Chamfered hexagonal tiling=== A [[Chamfer (geometry)|chamfer]]red hexagonal tiling replacing edges with new hexagons and transforms into another hexagonal tiling. In the limit, the original faces disappear, and the new hexagons degenerate into rhombi, and it becomes a [[rhombic tiling]]. {| class=wikitable !Hexagons (H) !colspan=3|Chamfered hexagons (cH) !Rhombi (daH) |- |[[File:Uniform tiling 63-t0.svg|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered hexagonal tiling.png|120px]] |[[File:Truncated rhombille tiling.png|120px]] |[[File:Chamfered_hexagonal_tiling2.png|120px]] |[[File:Rhombic_star_tiling.png|120px]] |} == Related tilings == The hexagons can be dissected into sets of 6 triangles. This process leads to two [[2-uniform tiling]]s, and the [[triangular tiling]]: {| class=wikitable !Regular tiling !Dissection !colspan=2|[[2-uniform tiling]]s !Regular tiling |- align=center |[[File:1-uniform n1.svg|120px]]
Original ![[File:Regular hexagon.svg|60px]]
[[File:Vertex type 3-3-3-3-3-3.svg|60px]] |[[File:2-uniform n10.svg|120px]]
1/3 dissected |[[File:2-uniform n19.svg|120px]]
2/3 dissected |[[File:1-uniform n11.svg|120px]]
fully dissected |- !Regular Tiling !Inset ! colspan="2" |2-Uniform Duals !Regular Tiling |- align=center |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Regular 2) 6.6.6.png|frameless|120x120px]]
Original ![[File:Insetting Polygon for Uniform Tilings 1.png|frameless|66x66px]] |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Two 8) 3.3.3.3.3.3; 3.3.6.6.png|frameless|120x120px]]
1/3 inset |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Two 9) 36; 34.6 1.png|frameless|120x120px]]
2/3 inset |[[File:Dual of Planar Tiling (Uniform Regular 1) 3.3.3.3.3.3 Soccer Variant.png|alt=|frameless|120x120px]]
fully inset |} The hexagonal tiling can be considered an ''elongated rhombic tiling'', where each vertex of the rhombic tiling is stretched into a new edge. This is similar to the relation of the [[Rhombic dodecahedron#Honeycomb|rhombic dodecahedron]] and the [[rhombo-hexagonal dodecahedron]] tessellations in 3 dimensions. {| class=wikitable |- align=center |[[File:Kah 3 6 romb.png|160px]]
Rhombic tiling |[[File:Uniform tiling 63-t0.svg|160px]]
Hexagonal tiling |[[File:Chicken Wire close-up.jpg|160px]]
Fencing uses this relation |} It is also possible to subdivide the prototiles of certain hexagonal tilings by two, three, four or nine equal pentagons: {| class=wikitable width=700 |- valign=top |[[File:Pent-Hex-Type1-2.png|175px]]
[[Pentagonal tiling]] type 1 with overlays of regular hexagons (each comprising 2 pentagons). |[[File:Pent-Hex-Type3-3.png|175px]]
pentagonal tiling type 3 with overlays of regular hexagons (each comprising 3 pentagons). |[[File:Pent-Hex-Type4-4.png|175px]]
Pentagonal tiling type 4 with overlays of semiregular hexagons (each comprising 4 pentagons). |[[File:Pent-Hex-Type3-9.png|175px]]
Pentagonal tiling type 3 with overlays of two sizes of regular hexagons (comprising 3 and 9 pentagons respectively). |} === Symmetry mutations=== This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of regular tilings with [[hexagon]]al faces, starting with the hexagonal tiling, with [[Schläfli symbol]] {6,n}, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|6|node|n|node}}, progressing to infinity. {{Hexagonal_regular_tilings}} This tiling is topologically related to regular polyhedra with [[vertex figure]] ''n''3, as a part of sequence that continues into the [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic plane]]. {{Order-3 tiling table}} It is similarly related to the uniform [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] polyhedra with vertex figure ''n''.6.6. {{Truncated figure2 table}} This tiling is also a part of a sequence of truncated rhombic polyhedra and tilings with [n,3] [[Coxeter group]] symmetry. The cube can be seen as a rhombic hexahedron where the rhombi are squares. The truncated forms have regular n-gons at the truncated vertices, and nonregular hexagonal faces. {{Dual quasiregular3 table}} == Wythoff constructions from hexagonal and triangular tilings == Like the [[Uniform polyhedron|uniform polyhedra]] there are eight [[uniform tiling]]s that can be based from the regular hexagonal tiling (or the dual [[triangular tiling]]). Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms, 7 which are topologically distinct. (The ''truncated triangular tiling'' is topologically identical to the hexagonal tiling.) {{Hexagonal tiling small table}} == Monohedral convex hexagonal tilings == There are 3 types of monohedral convex hexagonal tilings.Tilings and Patterns, Sec. 9.3 Other Monohedral tilings by convex polygons They are all [[isohedral figure|isohedral]]. Each has parametric variations within a fixed symmetry. Type 2 contains [[glide reflection]]s, and is 2-isohedral keeping chiral pairs distinct. {| class=wikitable |+ 3 types of monohedral convex hexagonal tilings !1||colspan=2|2||3 |- !p2, 2222||pgg, 22×||p2, 2222||p3, 333 |- |[[File:P6-type1.png|120px]]|||[[File:P6-type2.png|120px]]||[[File:P6-type2-chiral_coloring.png|120px]]|||[[File:P6-type3.png|120px]] |- align=center |[[File:Prototile_p6-type1.png|120px]]
b=e
B+C+D=360° |colspan=2|[[File:Prototile_p6-type2.png|120px]]
b=e, d=f
B+C+E=360° |[[File:Prototile_p6-type3.png|120px]]
a=f, b=c, d=e
B=D=F=120° |- align=center |[[File:Lattice_p6-type1.png|120px]]
2-tile lattice |colspan=2|[[File:Lattice_p6-type2.png|120px]]
4-tile lattice |[[File:Lattice_p6-type3.png|120px]]
3-tile lattice |} == Topologically equivalent tilings == Hexagonal tilings can be made with the identical {6,3} topology as the regular tiling (3 hexagons around every vertex). With isohedral faces, there are 13 variations. Symmetry given assumes all faces are the same color. Colors here represent the lattice positions.Tilings and Patterns, from list of 107 isohedral tilings, pp. 473–481 Single-color (1-tile) lattices are [[parallelogon]] hexagons. {| class=wikitable |+ 13 isohedrally-tiled hexagons |- align=center !colspan=2|pg (××)||p2 (2222)||p3 (333)||colspan=2|pmg (22*) |- align=center |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-1.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-2.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-3.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-6.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-9.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-10.png|100px]] |- align=center !colspan=3|pgg (22×)||p31m (3*3)||p2 (2222)||cmm (2*22)||p6m (*632) |- align=center |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-4.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-5.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-8.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-11.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-7.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-12.png|100px]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p6-13.png|100px]] |} Other isohedrally-tiled topological hexagonal tilings are seen as quadrilaterals and pentagons that are not edge-to-edge, but interpreted as colinear adjacent edges: {| class=wikitable |+ Isohedrally-tiled quadrilaterals |- align=center !colspan=2|pmg (22*)||colspan=3|pgg (22×)||cmm (2*22)||p2 (2222) |- align=center |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-18.png|100px]]
Parallelogram |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-20.png|100px]]
[[Trapezoid]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-19.png|100px]]
Parallelogram |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-19b.png|70px]]
[[Rectangle]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-17.png|100px]]
[[Parallelogram]] |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-21.png|100px]]
Rectangle |[[File:Isohedral_tiling_p4-22.png|100px]]
Rectangle |} {| class=wikitable |+ Isohedrally-tiled pentagons |- align=center !p2 (2222)||pgg (22×)||p3 (333) |- align=center |[[File:P5-type1.png|120px]] ||[[File:P5-type2.png|120px]] ||[[File:P5-type3.png|120px]] |} The 2-uniform and 3-uniform tessellations have a rotational degree of freedom which distorts 2/3 of the hexagons, including a colinear case that can also be seen as a non-edge-to-edge tiling of hexagons and larger triangles.Tilings and patterns, uniform tilings that are not edge-to-edge It can also be distorted into a [[Chirality (mathematics)|chiral]] 4-colored tri-directional weaved pattern, distorting some hexagons into [[parallelogram]]s. The weaved pattern with 2 colored faces have rotational [[List of planar symmetry groups#Wallpaper groups|632 (p6) symmetry]]. A [[Chevron (insignia)|chevron]] pattern has pmg (22*) symmetry, which is lowered to p1 (°) with 3 or 4 colored tiles. {| class=wikitable |- !Regular !Gyrated !Regular !Weaved !Chevron |- ! p6m, (*632) ! p6, (632) ! p6m (*632) ! p6 (632) ! p1 (°) |- |[[File:Uniform tiling 63-t12.svg|150px]] |[[File:Gyrated_hexagonal_tiling2.png|150px]] |[[File:Truncated rhombille tiling.png|150px]] |[[File:Weaved hexagonal tiling2.png|150px]] |[[File:Chevron hexagonal tiling-3-color.png|150px]] |- ! p3m1, (*333) ! p3, (333) ! p6m (*632) ! p2 (2222) ! p1 (°) |- |[[File:Uniform tiling 333-t012.svg|150px]] |[[File:Gyrated_hexagonal_tiling1.png|150px]] |[[File:Hexagonal tiling 4-colors.png|150px]] |[[File:Weaved hexagonal tiling.png|150px]] |[[File:Chevron hexagonal tiling-4-color.png|150px]] |} == Circle packing == The hexagonal tiling can be used as a [[circle packing]], placing equal diameter circles at the center of every point. Every circle is in contact with 3 other circles in the packing ([[kissing number]]).Order in Space: A design source book, Keith Critchlow, pp. 74–75, pattern 2 The gap inside each hexagon allows for one circle, creating the densest packing from the [[triangular tiling#A2 lattice and circle packings|triangular tiling]], with each circle contact with the maximum of 6 circles. :[[File:1-uniform-1-circlepack.svg|200px]] == Related regular complex apeirogons == There are 2 [[regular complex apeirogon]]s, sharing the vertices of the hexagonal tiling. Regular complex apeirogons have vertices and edges, where edges can contain 2 or more vertices. Regular apeirogons ''p''{''q''}''r'' are constrained by: 1/''p'' + 2/''q'' + 1/''r'' = 1. Edges have ''p'' vertices, and vertex figures are ''r''-gonal.Coxeter, Regular Complex Polytopes, pp. 111-112, p. 136. The first is made of 2-edges, three around every vertex, second has hexagonal edges, three around every vertex. A third complex apeirogon, sharing the same vertices, is quasiregular, which alternates 2-edges and 6-edges. {| class=wikitable |- |[[File:Complex apeirogon 2-12-3.png|160px]] |[[File:Complex apeirogon 6-4-3.png|160px]] |[[File:Truncated complex polygon 6-6-2.png|160px]] |- !2{12}3 or {{CDD|node_1|12|3node}} !6{4}3 or {{CDD|6node_1|4|3node}} !{{CDD|6node_1|6|node_1}} |} ==See also== {{Commons category|Order-3 hexagonal tiling}} *[[Hexagonal lattice]] *[[Hexagonal prismatic honeycomb]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] * [[Hexagonal tiling honeycomb]] *[[Hex map]] board game design == References == {{reflist}} * [[Coxeter|Coxeter, H.S.M.]] ''[[Regular Polytopes (book)|Regular Polytopes]]'', (3rd edition, 1973), Dover edition, {{ISBN|0-486-61480-8}} p. 296, Table II: Regular honeycombs * {{cite book|author1=[[Branko Grünbaum|Grünbaum, Branko]] |author2=Shephard, G. C. | title=Tilings and Patterns| location=New York | publisher=W. H. Freeman | year=1987 | isbn=0-7167-1193-1}} (Chapter 2.1: ''Regular and uniform tilings'', pp. 58–65) * {{The Geometrical Foundation of Natural Structure (book)|page=35}} * John H. Conway, Heidi Burgiel, [[Chaim Goodman-Strauss]], ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143320/https://akpeters.com/product.asp?ProdCode=2205] == External links == * {{MathWorld | urlname=HexagonalGrid | title=Hexagonal Grid}} ** {{MathWorld | urlname=RegularTessellation | title=Regular tessellation}} ** {{MathWorld | urlname=UniformTessellation | title=Uniform tessellation}} * {{KlitzingPolytopes|flat.htm#2D|2D Euclidean tilings|o3o6x - hexat - O3}} {{Honeycombs}} {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Euclidean tilings]] [[Category:Hexagonal tilings| ]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isohedral tilings]] [[Category:Regular tilings]] [[Category:Regular tessellations]]

pages.title: List of convex uniform tilings
pages.text:
[[File:Semi-regular-floor-3464.JPG|thumb|An example uniform tiling in the [[Archeological Museum of Seville]], [[Sevilla, Spain]]: [[rhombitrihexagonal tiling]]]] This table shows the 11 convex [[uniform tiling]]s (regular and semiregular) of the [[Euclidean geometry|Euclidean plane]], and their dual tilings. There are three regular and eight semiregular [[Tiling by regular polygons|tilings]] in the plane. The semiregular tilings form new tilings from their duals, each made from one type of irregular face. [[John Horton Conway|John Conway]] calls these uniform duals '''''Catalan tilings''''', in parallel to the [[Catalan solid]] polyhedra. Uniform tilings are listed by their [[vertex configuration]], the sequence of faces that exist on each vertex. For example ''4.8.8'' means one square and two octagons on a vertex. These 11 uniform tilings have 32 different ''[[uniform coloring]]s''. A uniform coloring allows identical sided polygons at a vertex to be colored differently, while still maintaining vertex-uniformity and transformational congruence between vertices. (Note: Some of the tiling images shown below are ''not'' color-uniform) In addition to the 11 convex uniform tilings, there are also [[Uniform tiling#Expanded lists of uniform tilings|14 nonconvex tilings]], using [[star polygon]]s, and reverse orientation vertex configurations. == Laves tilings== In the 1987 book, ''Tilings and Patterns'', [[Branko Grünbaum]] calls the vertex-uniform tilings ''Archimedean'' in parallel to the [[Archimedean solid]]s. Their [[Dual graph|dual tilings]] are called '''''Laves tilings''''' in honor of [[Crystallography|crystallographer]] [[Fritz Laves]].{{cite book | author1=[[Branko Grünbaum|Grünbaum, Branko]] | author2=[[G.C. Shephard|Shephard, G. C.]] | title=Tilings and Patterns | publisher=W. H. Freeman and Company | year=1987 | isbn=0-7167-1193-1 | pages=59, 96}} {{cite book | first = John H. | last = Conway | author-link = John Horton Conway | first2 = Heidi | last2 = Burgiel | author-link2 = | first3 = Chaim | last3 = Goodman-Strauss | author-link3 = Chaim Goodman-Strauss | title = The Symmetries of Things | chapter = Chapter 21, ''Naming the Archimedean and Catalan polyhedra and tilings, Euclidean Plane Tessellations'' | date = April 18, 2008 | url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143320/https://akpeters.com/product.asp?ProdCode=2205 | location = | publisher = [[A K Peters]] / [[CRC Press]] | page = 288 | isbn = 978-1-56881-220-5 }} They're also called '''Shubnikov–Laves tilings''' after [[Shubnikov, Alekseĭ Vasilʹevich]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=5rPnCAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA169&ots=kdjtDmwjqQ&dq=Shubnikov%E2%80%93Laves%20tilings&pg=PA169#v=onepage&q=Shubnikov%E2%80%93Laves%20tilings&f=false Encyclopaedia of Mathematics: Orbit - Rayleigh Equation] , 1991 [[John Horton Conway|John Conway]] calls the uniform duals '''''Catalan tilings''''', in parallel to the [[Catalan solid]] polyhedra. The Laves tilings have vertices at the centers of the regular polygons, and edges connecting centers of regular polygons that share an edge. The [[Prototile|tiles]] of the Laves tilings are called '''planigons'''. This includes the 3 regular tiles (triangle, square and hexagon) and 8 irregular ones.{{SpringerEOM|title=Planigon|id=Planigon&oldid=31578|first=A. B.|last=Ivanov}} Each vertex has edges evenly spaced around it. Three dimensional analogues of the ''planigons'' are called [[stereohedron]]s. These dual tilings are listed by their [[face configuration]], the number of faces at each vertex of a face. For example ''V4.8.8'' means isosceles triangle tiles with one corner with four triangles, and two corners containing eight triangles. {| class=wikitable |+ Eleven planigons !colspan=4|Triangles||colspan=3|Quadrilaterals||colspan=3|Pentagons||Hexagon |- valign=bottom align=center |[[File:Alchemy fire symbol.svg|40px]]

V3.3.3.4.4
{{CDD|2}} |[[File:Hexagon.svg|40px]]
V3.3.3.3.3.3
{{CDD|2}} |} == Convex uniform tilings of the Euclidean plane == All reflectional forms can be made by [[Wythoff construction]]s, represented by [[Wythoff symbol]]s, or [[Coxeter-Dynkin diagram]]s, each operating upon one of three [[Schwarz triangle#Triangles for the Euclidean plane|Schwarz triangle]] (4,4,2), (6,3,2), or (3,3,3), with symmetry represented by [[Coxeter group]]s: [4,4], [6,3], or [3[3]]. [[Alternation (geometry)|Alternated]] forms such as the snub can also be represented by special markups within each system. Only one uniform tiling can't be constructed by a Wythoff process, but can be made by an [[Elongation (geometry)|elongation]] of the triangular tiling. An orthogonal mirror construction [∞,2,∞] also exists, seen as two sets of parallel mirrors making a rectangular fundamental domain. If the domain is square, this symmetry can be doubled by a diagonal mirror into the [4,4] family. Families: * (4,4,2), {\tilde{BC}}_2, [4,4] - Symmetry of the regular [[square tiling]] ** {\tilde{I}}_1^2, [∞,2,∞] * (6,3,2), {\tilde{G}}_2, [6,3] - Symmetry of the regular [[hexagonal tiling]] and [[triangular tiling]]. ** (3,3,3), {\tilde{A}}_2, [3[3]] === The [4,4] group family === {| class="wikitable" !Uniform tilings
(Platonic and Archimedean) ![[Vertex figure]] and dual face

(called Laves or Catalan tilings) |- {{Uniform tiles db|Uniform tiling list table|Us}} {{Uniform tiles db|Uniform tiling list table|Uts}} {{Uniform tiles db|Uniform tiling list table|Uns}} |} === The [6,3] group family === {| class="wikitable" !Platonic and Archimedean tilings ![[Vertex figure]] and dual face

Another presentation of these four semi-planigons can be found in the below image, and it further explains the process of dualization. pages.title: Order-2 apeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform tiles db|Reg tiling stat table|Ua}}
In [[geometry]], an '''order-2 apeirogonal tiling''', '''apeirogonal dihedron''', or '''infinite dihedron'''<ref>Conway (2008), p. 263</ref> is a tiling of the [[plane (geometry)|plane]] consisting of two [[Apeirogon#Hyperbolic geometry|apeirogons]]. It may be considered an improper [[regular tiling]] of the [[Euclidean geometry|Euclidean]] plane, with [[Schläfli symbol]] {∞, 2}. Two apeirogons, joined along all their edges, can completely fill the entire plane as an apeirogon is infinite in size and has an [[interior angle]] of 180°, which is half of a full 360°.

==Related tilings and polyhedra==
The apeirogonal tiling is the arithmetic limit of the family of [[dihedron|dihedra]] {''p'', 2}, as ''p'' tends to [[infinity]], thereby turning the dihedron into a Euclidean tiling.

Similarly to the [[uniform polyhedra]] and the [[uniform tiling]]s, eight uniform tilings may be based from the regular apeirogonal tiling. The [[rectification (geometry)|rectified]] and [[cantellation (geometry)|cantellated]] forms are duplicated, and as two times infinity is also infinity, the [[truncation (geometry)|truncated]] and [[omnitruncation|omnitruncated]] forms are also duplicated, therefore reducing the number of unique forms to four: the apeirogonal tiling, the apeirogonal hosohedron, the [[apeirogonal prism]], and the [[apeirogonal antiprism]].
{{Order-2 Apeirogonal Tilings}}

== See also ==
* [[Order-3 apeirogonal tiling]] - hyperbolic tiling
* [[Order-4 apeirogonal tiling]] - hyperbolic tiling

pages.title: Pythagorean tiling
pages.text:
{{good article}}
[[File:Academ Periodic tiling by squares of two different sizes.svg|thumb|A Pythagorean tiling]]
[[File:Jacob Ochtervelt - Street Musicians at the Doorway of a House - WGA16622.jpg|thumb|''Street Musicians at the Doorway of a House'', [[Jacob Ochtervelt]], 1665. As observed by Nelsen<ref name="rbn"/> the floor tiles in this painting are set in the Pythagorean tiling]]
A '''Pythagorean tiling''' or '''two squares tessellation''' is a [[tessellation|tiling]] of a [[Euclidean geometry|Euclidean]] plane by [[Square (geometry)|square]]s of two different sizes, in which each square touches four squares of the other size on its four sides. Many proofs of the [[Pythagorean theorem|Pythagorean theorem]] are based on it,<ref>{{citation | last = Wells |first=David | year = 1991 | title = The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Geometry | publisher = Penguin Books | location = New York | isbn = 0-14-011813-6 | pages = 260–261 | contribution = two squares tessellation}}.</ref> explaining its name.<ref name="rbn"/> It is commonly used as a pattern for [[Tile#Floor tiles|floor tiles]]. When used for this, it is also known as a '''hopscotch pattern'''<ref>{{citation|title=How to Install Hopscotch Pattern Tiles|department=Home Guides|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|url=http://homeguides.sfgate.com/install-hopscotch-pattern-tiles-25897.html|accessdate=2016-12-12}}.</ref> or '''pinwheel pattern''',<ref>{{citation|title=Bathroom Remodeling|author=Editors of Fine Homebuilding|publisher=Taunton Press|year=2013|isbn=978-1-62710-078-6|page=45|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OLOlBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45}}. A schematic diagram illustrating this floor tile pattern appears earlier, on p. 42.</ref>
but it should not be confused with the mathematical [[pinwheel tiling]], an unrelated pattern.<ref>{{citation | last = Radin | first = C. | authorlink = Charles Radin | title = The Pinwheel Tilings of the Plane | journal = [[Annals of Mathematics]] | volume = 139 | issue = 3 | pages =661–702 | year=1994 | doi = 10.2307/2118575 | jstor = 2118575}}</ref>

This tiling has four-way [[rotational symmetry]] around each of its squares. When the ratio of the side lengths of the two squares is an [[irrational number]] such as the [[golden ratio]], its cross-sections form [[Aperiodic tiling|aperiodic sequences]] with a similar recursive structure to the [[Fibonacci word]]. Generalizations of this tiling to three dimensions have also been studied.

==Topology and symmetry==
The Pythagorean tiling is the unique tiling by squares of two different sizes that is both ''unilateral'' (no two squares have a common side) and ''equitransitive'' (each two squares of the same size can be mapped into each other by a symmetry of the tiling).<ref name="mms">{{citation
 | last1 = Martini | first1 = Horst
 | last2 = Makai | first2 = Endre
 | last3 = Soltan | first3 = Valeriu
 | issue = 2
 | journal = Beiträge zur Algebra und Geometrie
 | mr = 1642720
 | pages = 481–495
 | title = Unilateral tilings of the plane with squares of three sizes
 | url = http://www.emis.de/journals/BAG/vol.39/no.2/b39h2mar.ps.gz
 | volume = 39
 | year = 1998}}.</ref>

Topologically, the Pythagorean tiling has the same structure as the [[truncated square tiling]] by squares and regular [[octagon]]s.<ref>{{citation
 | last1 = Grünbaum | first1 = Branko | author1-link = Branko Grünbaum
 | last2 = Shephard | first2 = G. C. | author2-link = Geoffrey Colin Shephard
 | page = 171
 | publisher = W. H. Freeman
 | title = Tilings and Patterns
 | year = 1987}}.</ref> The smaller squares in the Pythagorean tiling are adjacent to four larger tiles, as are the squares in the truncated square tiling, while the larger squares in the Pythagorean tiling are adjacent to eight neighbors that alternate between large and small, just as the octagons in the truncated square tiling. However, the two tilings have different sets of symmetries, because the truncated square tiling is symmetric under mirror reflections whereas the Pythagorean tiling isn't. Mathematically, this can be explained by saying that the truncated square tiling has [[dihedral group|dihedral]] symmetry around the center of each tile, while the Pythagorean tiling has a smaller [[cyclic group|cyclic]] set of symmetries around the corresponding points, giving it [[Wallpaper group#Group p4|p4 symmetry]].<ref>{{harvtxt|Grünbaum|Shephard|1987}}, p. 42.</ref> It is a [[chiral]] pattern, meaning that it is impossible to superpose it on top of its mirror image using only translations and rotations.

A [[uniform tiling]] is a tiling in which each tile is a regular polygon and in which every vertex can be mapped to every other vertex by a symmetry of the tiling. Usually, uniform tilings additionally are required to have tiles that meet edge-to-edge, but if this requirement is relaxed then there are eight additional uniform tilings. Four are formed from infinite strips of squares or equilateral triangles, and three are formed from equilateral triangles and regular hexagons. The remaining one is the Pythagorean tiling.<ref>{{harvtxt|Grünbaum|Shephard|1987}}, pp. 73–74.</ref>

==Pythagorean theorem and dissections==
[[File:Pythagorean dissections.svg|thumb|upright=1.5|left|The five-piece dissections used in the proofs by [[Al-Nayrizi]] and [[Thābit ibn Qurra]] (left) and by [[Henry Perigal]] (right)]]
This tiling is called the Pythagorean tiling because it has been used as the basis of proofs of the [[Pythagorean theorem]] by the ninth-century Islamic mathematicians [[Al-Nayrizi]] and [[Thābit ibn Qurra]], and by the 19th-century British amateur mathematician [[Henry Perigal]].<ref name="rbn">{{citation|title=Paintings, plane tilings, and proofs|first=Roger B.|last=Nelsen|journal=Math Horizons|date=November 2003|pages=5–8|url=http://www-stat.wharton.upenn.edu/~steele/Publications/Books/CSMC/New%20Problems/paintings.pdf}}. Reprinted in {{citation|title=The Edge of the Universe: Celebrating Ten Years of Math Horizons|series=Spectrum Series|publisher=Mathematical Association of America|first1=Deanna|last1=Haunsperger|first2=Stephen|last2=Kennedy|year=2007|isbn=978-0-88385-555-3|pages=295–298}}. See also {{citation|title=Charming proofs: a journey into elegant mathematics|volume=42|series=Dolciani mathematical expositions|first1=Claudi|last1=Alsina|first2=Roger B.|last2=Nelsen|publisher=Mathematical Association of America|year=2010|isbn=978-0-88385-348-1|pages=168–169}}.</ref><ref name="gnf"/><ref>{{citation
 | last1 = Aguiló | first1 = Francesc
 | last2 = Fiol | first2 = Miquel Angel
 | last3 = Fiol | first3 = Maria Lluïsa
 | doi = 10.2307/2589179
 | issue = 4
 | journal = American Mathematical Monthly
 | mr = 1763064
 | pages = 341–352
 | title = Periodic tilings as a dissection method
 | volume = 107
 | year = 2000}}.</ref><ref>{{harvtxt|Grünbaum|Shephard|1987}}, p. 94.</ref> If the sides of the two squares forming the tiling are the numbers ''a'' and ''b'', then the closest distance between corresponding points on congruent squares is ''c'', where ''c'' is the length of the [[hypotenuse]] of a [[right triangle]] having sides ''a'' and ''b''.<ref name="ow"/> For instance, in the illustration to the left, the two squares in the Pythagorean tiling have side lengths 5 and 12 units long, and the side length of the tiles in the overlaying square tiling is 13, based on the [[Pythagorean triple]] (5,12,13).

By overlaying a square grid of side length ''c'' onto the Pythagorean tiling, it may be used to generate a five-piece [[Dissection problem|dissection]] of two unequal squares of sides ''a'' and ''b'' into a single square of side ''c'', showing that the two smaller squares have the same area as the larger one. Similarly, overlaying two Pythagorean tilings may be used to generate a six-piece dissection of two unequal squares into a different two unequal squares.<ref name="gnf">{{citation|title=Dissections: Plane & Fancy|first=Greg N.|last=Frederickson|pages=30–31|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1997}}.</ref>

== Aperiodic cross sections ==
[[File:Pythagorean tiling section.svg|thumb|upright=1.25|An aperiodic sequence generated from tilings by two squares whose side lengths form the [[golden ratio]]]]

Although the Pythagorean tiling is itself periodic (it has a [[square lattice]] of translational symmetries) its [[Cross section (geometry)|cross sections]] can be used to generate one-dimensional [[aperiodic tiling|aperiodic]] sequences.<ref name="cq">{{citation|title=Crystallography of Quasicrystals: Concepts, Methods and Structures|volume=126|series=Springer Series in Materials Science|first1=Walter|last1=Steurer|first2=Sofia|last2=Deloudi|publisher=Springer|year=2009|isbn=978-3-642-01898-5|doi=10.1007/978-3-642-01899-2|contribution=3.5.3.7 The Klotz construction|pages=91–92}}.</ref>

In the "Klotz construction" for aperiodic sequences (Klotz is a German word for a block), one forms a Pythagorean tiling with two squares whose sizes are chosen to make the ratio between the two side lengths be an [[irrational number]] ''x''. Then, one chooses a line parallel to the sides of the squares, and forms a sequence of binary values from the sizes of the squares crossed by the line: a 0 corresponds to a crossing of a large square and a 1 corresponds to a crossing of a small square. In this sequence, the relative proportion of 0s and 1s will be in the ratio ''x'':1. This proportion cannot be achieved by a periodic sequence of 0s and 1s, because it is irrational, so the sequence is aperiodic.<ref name="cq"/>

If ''x'' is chosen as the [[golden ratio]], the sequence of 0s and 1s generated in this way has the same recursive structure as the [[Fibonacci word]]: it can be split into substrings of the form "01" and "0" (that is, there are no two consecutive ones) and if these two substrings are consistently replaced by the shorter strings "0" and "1" then another string with the same structure results.<ref name="cq"/>

==Related results==
According to [[Keller's conjecture]], any tiling of the plane by congruent squares must include two squares that meet edge-to-edge.<ref>The truth of his conjecture for two-dimensional tilings was known already to Keller, but it was since proven false for dimensions eight and above. For a recent survey on results related to this conjecture, see {{citation
 | last = Zong | first = Chuanming
 | doi = 10.1090/S0273-0979-05-01050-5
 | issue = 2
 | journal = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society | series = New Series
 | mr = 2133310
 | pages = 181–211
 | title = What is known about unit cubes
 | volume = 42
 | year = 2005}}.</ref> None of the squares in the Pythagorean tiling meet edge-to-edge,<ref name="mms"/> but this fact does not violate Keller's conjecture because the tiles have different sizes, so they are not all congruent to each other.

The Pythagorean tiling may be generalized to a three-dimensional tiling of [[Euclidean space]] by cubes of two different sizes, which also is unilateral and equitransitive. Attila Bölcskei calls this three-dimensional tiling the ''Rogers filling''. He conjectures that, in any dimension greater than three, there is again a unique unilateral and equitransitive way of tiling space by [[hypercube]]s of two different sizes.<ref>{{citation
 | last = Bölcskei | first = Attila
 | issue = 3–4
 | journal = Publicationes Mathematicae Debrecen
 | mr = 1874434
 | pages = 317–326
 | title = Filling space with cubes of two sizes
 | volume = 59
 | year = 2001}}. See also {{harvtxt|Dawson|1984}}, which includes an illustration of the three-dimensional tiling, credited to "Rogers" but cited to a 1960 paper by [[Richard K. Guy]]: {{citation
 | last = Dawson | first = R. J. M.
 | doi = 10.1016/0097-3165(84)90007-4
 | issue = 2
 | journal = Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series A
 | mr = 734979
 | pages = 221–229
 | title = On filling space with different integer cubes
 | volume = 36
 | year = 1984}}.</ref>

Burns and Rigby found several [[prototile]]s, including the [[Koch snowflake]], that may be used to tile the plane only by using copies of the prototile in two or more different sizes.<ref>{{citation|title=78.13 Fractal tilings|journal=Mathematical Gazette|first=Aidan|last=Burns|volume=78|issue=482|year=1994|pages=193–196|jstor=3618577}}. {{citation|title=79.51 Tiling the plane with similar polygons of two sizes|journal=Mathematical Gazette|first=John|last=Rigby|volume=79|issue=486|year=1995|pages=560–561|jstor=3618091}}.</ref> An earlier paper by Danzer, Grünbaum, and Shephard provides another example, a convex pentagon that tiles the plane only when combined in two sizes.<ref>Figure 3 of {{citation
 | last1 = Danzer | first1 = Ludwig
 | last2 = Grünbaum | first2 = Branko | author2-link = Branko Grünbaum
 | last3 = Shephard | first3 = G. C. | author3-link = Geoffrey Colin Shephard
 | doi = 10.2307/2320829
 | issue = 8
 | journal = The American Mathematical Monthly
 | mr = 1540019
 | pages = 568–570+583–585
 | title = Unsolved Problems: Can All Tiles of a Tiling Have Five-Fold Symmetry?
 | volume = 89
 | year = 1982}}.</ref> Although the Pythagorean tiling uses two different sizes of squares, the square does not have the same property as these prototiles of only tiling by similarity, because it also is possible to tile the plane using only squares of a single size.

==Application==
An early structural application of the Pythagorean tiling appears in the works of [[Leonardo da Vinci]], who considered it among several other potential patterns for [[Joist|floor joists]].<ref>{{citation
 | last1 = Sánchez | first1 = José
 | last2 = Escrig | first2 = Félix
 | date = December 2011
 | doi = 10.1260/0266-3511.26.4.289
 | issue = 4
 | journal = International Journal of Space Structures
 | pages = 289–302
 | title = Frames designed by Leonardo with short pieces: An analytical approach
 | volume = 26}}.</ref> This tiling has also long been used decoratively, for [[floor tile]]s or other similar patterns, as can be seen for instance in [[Jacob Ochtervelt]]'s painting ''Street Musicians at the Doorway of a House'' (1665).<ref name="rbn"/> It has been suggested that seeing a similar tiling in the palace of [[Polycrates]] may have provided [[Pythagoras]] with the original inspiration for his theorem.<ref name="ow">{{citation
 | last1 = Ostermann | first1 = Alexander
 | last2 = Wanner | first2 = Gerhard
 | contribution = Thales and Pythagoras
 | doi = 10.1007/978-3-642-29163-0_1
 | pages = 3–26
 | publisher = Springer
 | series = Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics
 | title = Geometry by Its History
 | year = 2012}}. See in particular [https://books.google.com/books?id=eOSqPHwWJX8C&pg=PA15 pp. 15–16].</ref>
